factoid: The soldiers and officers rode beyond the village.
The soldiers and officers continually met and overtook soldiers and officers of various regiments.
The soldiers and officers saw on their left some entrenchments being thrown up.
The freshly dug clay of the entrenchments showed up red.
Several battalions of soldiers swarmed in the earthworks like a host of white ants.
The soldiers were in their shirt sleeves despite the cold wind.
Spadefuls of red clay were continually being thrown up from behind the bank by unseen hands.
Prince Andrew and the officer rode up, looked at the entrenchment, and rode on again.
Just behind the entrenchment, the soldiers and officers came upon some dozens of soldiers, continually replaced by others, who ran from the entrenchment.
The soldiers and officers had to hold their noses and put their horses to a trot to escape from the poisoned atmosphere of these latrines.
The staff officer said, 'Voilà l’agrément des camps, monsieur le prince.'
The staff officer said, 'This is a pleasure one gets in camp, Prince.'
The soldiers and officers rode up the opposite hill.
From there the French could already be seen.
Prince Andrew stopped and began examining the position.
The staff officer said, 'That’s our battery,' and indicated the highest point.
The staff officer said, 'It’s in charge of the queer fellow we saw without his boots. You can see everything from there; let’s go there, Prince.'
Prince Andrew said, 'Thank you very much, I will go on alone. Please don’t trouble yourself further.'
The staff officer remained behind.
Prince Andrew rode on alone.
The farther forward and nearer the enemy Prince Andrew went, the more orderly and cheerful were the troops.
The greatest disorder and depression had been in the baggage train that Prince Andrew had passed that morning on the Znaim road seven miles away from the French.
At Grunth some apprehension and alarm could be felt.
The nearer Prince Andrew came to the French lines, the more confident the appearance of our troops.
The soldiers in their greatcoats were ranged in lines.
The sergeants major and company officers were counting the men.
The sergeants major and company officers poked the last man in each section in the ribs.
The sergeants major and company officers told the last man in each section to hold his hand up.
Soldiers scattered over the whole place were dragging logs and brushwood and building shelters with merry chatter and laughter.
Around the fires sat others, dressed and undressed, drying their shirts and leg bands or mending boots or overcoats, and crowding round the boilers and porridge cookers.
In one company dinner was ready.

The soldiers were gazing eagerly at the steaming boiler, waiting until the sample, which a quartermaster sergeant was carrying in a wooden bowl to an officer who sat on a log before his shelter, had been tasted.
Another company, lucky because not all companies had vodka, crowded around a pockmarked, broad-shouldered sergeant major who, tilting a keg, filled one after another the canteen lids held out to him.

The soldiers lifted the canteen lids to their lips with reverential faces, emptied them, rolled the vodka in their mouths, and walked away from the sergeant major with brightened expressions, licking their lips and wiping them on the sleeves of their greatcoats.

All their faces were as serene as if all this were happening at home awaiting peaceful encampment, and not within sight of the enemy before an action in which at least half of them would be left on the field.

After passing a chasseur regiment and in the lines of the Kiev grenadiers, near the shelter of the regimental commander, Prince Andrew came out in front of a platoon of grenadiers before whom lay a naked man.
Two soldiers held the naked man while two others were flourishing their switches and striking him regularly on his bare back.
The naked man shrieked unnaturally.

A stout major paced up and down the line, repeating regardless of the screams: 'It’s a shame for a soldier to steal; a soldier must be honest, honorable, and brave, but if he robs his fellows there is no honor in him, he’s a scoundrel. Go on! Go on!'
The swishing sound of the strokes and the desperate but unnatural screams continued.
The major said, 'Go on, go on!'
A young officer with a bewildered and pained expression on his face stepped away from the naked man and looked round inquiringly at the adjutant as the adjutant rode by.
